00001 ################################################################################
00002 # WeBWorK mod_perl (c) 2000-2002 WeBWorK Project
00003 # $Id$
00004 ################################################################################
00005 
00006 package WeBWorK::EquationCache;
00007 
00008 =head1 NAME
00009 
00010 WeBWorK::EquationCache - create and cache images of TeX equations.
00011 
00012 =head1 SYNPOSIS
00013 
00014  my $cache = WeBWorK::EquationCache->new(cacheDB => "/path/to/equationcache.db");
00015  my $imageName = $cache->lookup('\[3x^2\]');
00016 
00017 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00018 
00019 WeBWorK::PG::EquationCache maintains a list of unique identifiers for TeX
00020 strings. The unique identifier is based on an MD5 hash of the TeX string, and a
00021 sequence number. Before calcuating the MD5 hash of a TeX string, all whitespace
00022 is removed.
00023 
00024 =head2 FILE FORMAT
00025 
00026 The cache database file is a text file consisting of lines of the following
00027 form:
00028 
00029  md5_hash     sequence_number     tex_string
00030 
00031 Any amount of whitespace may separate the fields. Lines which do not conform to
00032 this format are ignored. Any string of characters beginning with `#' and
00033 extending to the end of the line is also ignored.
00034 
00035 =cut
00036 
00037 use strict;
00038 use warnings;
00039 use Digest::MD5 qw(md5_hex);
00040 use Fcntl qw(:DEFAULT :flock);
00041 BEGIN { my @_junk = (O_RDWR,O_CREAT,LOCK_EX) } # get rid of "subroutine redefined" warnings
00042 
00043 =head1 METHODS
00044 
00045 =over
00046 
00047 =item new(%options)
00048 
00049 Returns a new EquationCache object. C<%options> must contain the following
00050 entries:
00051 
00052  cacheDB => path to image cache database file
00053 
00054 If cacheDB is the empty string, don't use a cache file and assume that there
00055 are no md5 collisions.
00056 
00057 =cut
00058 
00059 sub new {
00060     my ($invocant, %options) = @_;
00061     my $class = ref $invocant || $invocant;
00062     my $self = {
00063         %options,
00064     };
00065     
00066     bless $self, $class;
00067 }
00068 
00069 =item lookup
00070 
00071 Looks up a TeX string in the database. A unique identifier for the cached image
00072 is returned. If necessary, the string is added to the database.
00073 
00074 =cut
00075 
00076 sub lookup {
00077     my ($self, $tex) = @_;
00078     # There are several ways to normalize TeX strings.  Use only
00079     # one of them.
00080 
00081     # Option 1 (default): remove leading and trailing whitespace, and
00082     # compress all other whitespace to single spaces.
00083     $tex =~ s/^\s+//g;
00084     $tex =~ s/\s+$//g;
00085     $tex =~ s/\s+/ /g;
00086     # Option 2 (the old default): remove all whitespace
00087     # $tex =~ s/\s+//g;
00088 
00089     my $md5 = md5_hex($tex);
00090     
00091     my $db = $self->{cacheDB};
00092     unless($db) { return($md5 ."1"); }
00093     sysopen(DB, $db, O_RDWR|O_CREAT)
00094         or die "failed to create/open cacheDB $db: $!";
00095     flock(DB, LOCK_EX)
00096         or die "failed to write-lock cacheDB $db: $!";
00097     
00098     my $line = 0;
00099     my $max = 0;
00100     my $match = 0;
00101     local $/ = "\n";
00102     while (<DB>) {
00103         # find matching MD5 hashes
00104         next unless m/^$md5\s+(\d+)\s+(.*)$/;
00105         if ($tex = $2) {
00106             # the TeX string matches: use this instance number and stop looking
00107             $match = $1;
00108             last;
00109         } else {
00110             # the TeX string doesn't match: record instance number and keep looking
00111             $max = $1 if $1 > $max;
00112         }
00113     }
00114     
00115     unless ($match) {
00116         # no match: invent a new instance number and add TeX string to DB
00117         $match = $max + 1;
00118         seek(DB, 0, 2); # we should already be at EOF, but what the hell.
00119         print DB "$md5\t$match\t$tex\n";
00120     }
00121     
00122     close(DB);
00123     return "$md5$match";
00124 }
00125 
00126 1;
